Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant infringed the plaintiff's trademark rights under the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Ex parte motion for default judgment
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant's use of TEAYAMA is visually and phonetically similar to TEAVANA; evidence supports similarity in services but lacks proof of goodwill depreciation or damages
Decision_Outcome: Injunction granted, damages awarded ($10,000), claims of passing-off and goodwill depreciation dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove infringement and likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Defendant failed to respond, leading to default judgment
Legal_Rule: Sections 19, 20, and 7(b) of the Trade-marks Act govern exclusive use, infringement, and confusion
Procedural_Issue: Default judgment due to defendant's non-response
Grounds_for_Claim: Use of confusingly similar mark (TEAYAMA) for similar tea-related services
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial relief granted: infringement established under Sections 19 and 20, Section 7(b) violated
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Procedurally fair as ex parte motion was justified by defendant’s failure to respond
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similarity between TEAVANA and TEAYAMA in appearance, sound, and services offered
Applicant_Challenge: Proving likelihood of confusion and entitlement to remedies
Court_Result: Plaintiff succeeded on infringement, failed on passing-off and goodwill claims
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, trademark registration records, comparative branding analysis
Outcome: Injunction issued, $10,000 damages awarded, other claims dismissed
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of trademark infringement based on confusing similarity
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian intellectual property law
Governing_Rule: Trade-marks Act provisions on infringement and confusion
